title: 104_hr2116
content: The Act may be cited as the National Voter Opportunity To Inform Congress Effectively on a Flat Tax and a Cap on Tax Increases Act of 1995 (National VOICE on a Flat Tax and Cap on Tax Increases Act of 1995). The Congress finds that the right to vote is fundamental, citizens should have a voice in Congress, and there is a demand for less taxation. The Act aims to allow citizens to voice their opinion on a flat income tax system and require a majority vote to raise taxes. The Act aims to allow citizens to voice their opinion on a flat income tax system and require a majority vote to raise taxes. Additionally, it proposes a national nonbinding referendum on a flat tax on income and a national vote on tax increases at the 1996 general election to study the feasibility of conducting similar referenda on other important issues in the future. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "nonbinding referendum," "advisory questions," "general election," and "State election agency." The nonbinding referendum involves advisory questions on a flat tax and national vote on tax increases to be included in the 1996 general election ballot. The curr_chunk is about the agency in each State and territory responsible for conducting general elections. The curr_chunk discusses procedures for national voter opportunity to inform Congress effectively on a flat tax and requiring a national vote on tax increases nonbinding referendum. The Act mandates the inclusion of advisory questions on the 1996 general election ballot regarding a flat tax on income and requiring a national vote on tax increases in every congressional district, delegate district, resident commissioner district, the District of Columbia, and U.S. territories. The Clerk of the U.S. House of Representatives and the Secretary of the U.S. Senate will certify the ballot title and questions by June 30, 1996. The Act mandates including advisory questions on the 1996 general election ballot regarding a flat tax on income and requiring a national vote on tax increases in every congressional district, delegate district, resident commissioner district, the District of Columbia, and U.S. territories. The procedures for printing and preparing the ballots will follow the same guidelines as elections for Members of Congress. The bill authorizes $5,000,000 for states to prepare nonbinding referendum questions for the 1996 general election. Reimbursements will be made from Congress' franking accounts, with equal amounts from the House of Representatives and the Senate. The bill authorizes $5,000,000 for states to prepare nonbinding referendum questions for the 1996 general election. Reimbursements will be made from Congress' franking accounts, with equal amounts from the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Clerk of the United States House of Representatives and the Secretary of the United States Senate shall ensure proper application and reimbursement of expenses. State election agencies will tabulate and certify voting results similar to elections for Members of Congress. Certified results will be transmitted to Congress, Members, and Judiciary Committees. The official election results of nonbinding referenda will be certified by the State election agency to the Clerk of the United States House of Representatives and the Secretary of the United States Senate. Results will be transmitted to each Member of Congress and reviewed by the Committees on Ways and Means and Finance, with recommendations reported back to the full House and Senate. Within 6 months of the general election, recommendations for response will be reported to the full House and Senate. State election agencies must provide comments on future nonbinding referenda procedures within 90 days of the election, which will be forwarded to the respective committees on the Judiciary of the House of Representatives and Senate. The Act will take effect upon its enactment.
